channel.title: American History
channel.description:
Meh, well.... i need to answer all these for an american history class... 11 days left.
Unit 3 – Civil Rights and Civil Liberties
The Bill of Rights are which Amendments?
What were the two original purposes of the Bill of Rights? 1)
2)
Explain the Amendments and the other questions asked: First Amendment:
Establishment clause:
Free Exercise clause:
Explain the following Supreme Court cases, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Engel v. Vitale (1962):
Tinker v. Des Moines (1969):
Schenck v. US (1919):
NY Times v. US (1971):
Second Amendment:
Third Amendment:
Fourth Amendment:
Explain the following Supreme Court case, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Mapp v. Ohio (1961):
NJ v. TLO (1985):
Vernonia v. Acton (1995):
Fifth Amendment: - - - -
Sixth Amendment: - - - -
Explain the following Supreme Court case, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Gideon v. Wainwright (1963):
Miranda v. Arizona (1966): (Fifth and Sixth Amendments)
Seventh Amendment:
Eighth Amendment:
Ninth Amendment:
Explain the following Supreme Court case, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Roe v. Wade (1973): (a right to _______________)
Tenth Amendment:
Explain the following Supreme Court case, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Muller v. Oregon (1908):
Eleventh Amendment:
Twelfth Amendment:
Thirteenth Amendment:
Fourteenth Amendment: (explain all three parts, including the due process clause) - - - due process clause:
Explain the following Supreme Court case, concentrating on how this amendment affected the decision: Plessy v. Ferguson (1896):
Brown v. Board of Education (1954):
Fifteenth Amendment:
Sixteenth Amendment:
Seventeenth Amendment:
Eighteenth Amendment:
Nineteenth Amendment:
Twentieth Amendment:
Twenty First Amendment:
Twenty Second Amendment:
Twenty Third Amendment:
Twenty Fourth Amendment:
Twenty Fifth Amendment:
Twenty Sixth Amendment:
Twenty Seventh Amendment:
Explain the Amendment process: National level: 1)
2)
State level: 1)
2)
Other civil rights / civil liberty items: Dred Scott case: (basic background / detailed description of decision / what amendment nullifies the decision of this case?)
Black codes: (define & examples)
Jim Crow laws: (define & examples)
Civil Rights Act of 1964: (Main provisions with their Titles. Ex. Title 1 provided for the ….)
Voting Rights Act of 1965: (Main provisions)
Little Rock Nine (1957): (Explain their role in the civil rights movement. Be sure to mention the roles of the governor and the president. This is a great example of Federalism.)
Seneca Falls Convention (1848):
“Declaration of Sentiments”
Elizabeth Cady Stanton:
Unit 4 – Public Opinion / Political Action Political socialization is done primarily by who?
Unit 5 – Media & Politics
What were FDR’s “fireside chats”:
Why were they so important to the nation?
What effect did Watergate and Vietnam have on the nation?
Unit 6 – Political Parties Define political party:
What were the first two political parties?
Why were they created?
Identify the political party of the following political leaders: George Washington – (Late 1700’s) Alexander Hamilton – (Late 1700’s) John Adams – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s) John Marshall – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s) Thomas Jefferson – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s) James Madison – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s) Andrew Jackson – (1820’s & 1830’s) Abraham Lincoln – (1850’s & 1860’s) William Jennings Bryan – (1890’s) Theodore Roosevelt – (Late 1800’s to 1912) Herbert Hoover – (1920’s & early 1930’s) Franklin Delano Roosevelt – (1930’s & 1940’s) Dwight D. Eisenhower – (1950’s) Richard Nixon – (1950’s to 1970’s) John F. Kennedy – (1960’s) Lyndon Baines Johnson – (1960’s) Henry Ford – (1970’s) Jimmy Carter – (1970’s) Ronald Reagan – (1980’s) George H. W. Bush – (1980’s & 1990’s) Bill Clinton – (1990’s) George W. Bush – (2000’s)
What was the New Deal?
Who did it help?
Who didn’t like it & why?
What are some famous Third Parties?
What makes a Third Party successful? Unit 7 –Nominations, Campaigns, Elections, & Voting When was the Progressive Era?
It started as a reaction to what?
What were the goals of the Progressives?
Define the following reforms that started during the Progressive Era: Primaries:
Referendums:
Primaries:
Pendelton Act (1883):
Define suffrage:
What Amendments deal with it?
What is the electoral college?
How are the number of electoral college votes determined per state?
How are they allocated to the candidates? Unit 8 – Special Interests Define Lobbying:
Lobbying is part of what?
How does lobbying corrupt our political system?
If lobbying is harmful to our democracy, why do we still allow it?
And a bunch more
feel free to answer some lol, i would be much appreciative. and for the love of god, nobody post a google link please.

item.title: American History
item.dc:creator: @John2.0 John2.0
item.description:
@John2.0 wrote:

i thought i got the point across but sorry if i didn’t =\ (now looking back on my post i completely forgot to give any explanation whatsoever). this was supposed to be more of a time saver than anything else. I’m perfectly capable of finding these, but it’ll take time and i have very little time left till school starts and i have a boatload of other stuff that needs to be done. Yes, it sounds like one of those “cry me a river, you procrastinated” kind of stories, but i moved and as everyone does… procrastinated the first month but otherwise I’ve been busy between moving and funerals this summer.

I understand your frustration, but… it was still unnecessary lol

Read full topic

Unit 4 – Public Opinion / Political Action
Political socialization is done primarily by who?

Unit 5 – Media & Politics

What were FDR’s “fireside chats”:

Why were they so important to the nation?

What effect did Watergate and Vietnam have on the nation?

Unit 6 – Political Parties
Define political party:

What were the first two political parties?

Why were they created?

Identify the political party of the following political leaders:
George Washington – (Late 1700’s)
Alexander Hamilton – (Late 1700’s)
John Adams – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s)
John Marshall – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s)
Thomas Jefferson – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s)
James Madison – (Late 1700’s & Early 1800’s)
Andrew Jackson – (1820’s & 1830’s)
Abraham Lincoln – (1850’s & 1860’s)
William Jennings Bryan – (1890’s)
Theodore Roosevelt – (Late 1800’s to 1912)
Herbert Hoover – (1920’s & early 1930’s)
Franklin Delano Roosevelt – (1930’s & 1940’s)
Dwight D. Eisenhower – (1950’s)
Richard Nixon – (1950’s to 1970’s)
John F. Kennedy – (1960’s)
Lyndon Baines Johnson – (1960’s)
Henry Ford – (1970’s)
Jimmy Carter – (1970’s)
Ronald Reagan – (1980’s)
George H. W. Bush – (1980’s & 1990’s)
Bill Clinton – (1990’s)
George W. Bush – (2000’s)

What was the New Deal?

Who did it help?


Who didn’t like it & why?

What are some famous Third Parties?

What makes a Third Party successful?
Unit 7 –Nominations, Campaigns, Elections, & Voting
When was the Progressive Era?

It started as a reaction to what?

What were the goals of the Progressives?

Define the following reforms that started during the Progressive Era:
Primaries:

Referendums:




Primaries:



Pendelton Act (1883):

Define suffrage:

What Amendments deal with it?

What is the electoral college?

How are the number of electoral college votes determined per state?


How are they allocated to the candidates?

Unit 8 – Special Interests
Define Lobbying:

Lobbying is part of what?

How does lobbying corrupt our political system?

If lobbying is harmful to our democracy, why do we still allow it?

And a bunch more
